courses.description: This course aims to provide students with basic research methods, data analysis, writing and presentation skills in the field of Biodiversity, Environmental Management, Sustainability and Technology (BEST). Also, this course provides guidelines and educates students for conducting research responsibly and at a high ethical standard.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
- Orientation

- Writing and presentation skills

- Ethics

- Research highlights

- Case studies

- Discussion
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Discussion with students

- Self-reflection of teacher(s)

- Feedback from alumni

- Feedback from visiting committee

- Regular programme reviews

courses.subject: BEST
courses.title: Techniques in Molecular Biology, Genomics and Bioinformatics
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of key techniques and tools in molecular biology, genomics, and bioinformatics. Students will gain insights into fundamental methodologies such as DNA/RNA extraction, modification, and amplification, gene cloning, sequencing technologies, and CRISPR-based genome editing. The curriculum also delves into genomic data analysis, including transcriptomics, functional genomics, and epigenetics, alongside bioinformatics tools for sequence alignment, comparison, and functional annotation. Through engaging lectures and practical computational exercises, students will develop the skills necessary to analyze and interpret complex biological data, emphasizing the integration of molecular biology techniques with computational strategies to address biological challenges. Designed to build a robust theoretical foundation, this course equips students for advanced studies or careers in research, biotechnology, and related disciplines.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
Class 1: introduction to molecular biology techniques

Class 2: nucleic acid manipulation and amplification

Class 3: recombine DNA technology

Class 4: sequencing technologies

Class 5: genome editing technologies

Class 6: introduction to genomics

Class 7: chromatin and histone

Class 8: epigenome and epigenetics

Class 9: single-cell and spatial genomics

Class 10: sequence alignment and assembly

Class 11: transcriptomics and functional genomics

Class 12: presentation 1

Class 13: presentation 2

courses.subject: BEST
courses.title: Field Survey
courses.description: This course introduces basic fieldwork techniques and analytical methods in conducting field surveys. Students are required to conduct fieldwork in different habitats. Conventional and latest methods in ecological and environmental evaluation will also be introduced in this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

- demonstrate proficiency in ecological and field surveying techniques, including sample collection, data collection, data analysis, basic statistics, and data reporting.

- analyze habitats and populations to understand their dynamics and interactions.

- observe, record, and quantify ecological targets accurately using standard methodologies.

- understand and apply concepts of experimental design and hypothesis testing in ecological research.

- present and report findings and ideas effectively using charts, graphs, diagrams and tables.

- integrate theory and practice through field exercises.

- appreciate the nature through field trips and site visits and understand how the environment is closely related to us.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Basic fieldwork techniques and analytical methods in conducting field surveys

- Conducting fieldwork in different habitats

- Analysing habitats and populations

- Using conventional and latest methods in ecological and environmental evaluation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Discussion with students

- Self-reflection of teacher(s)

- Feedback from alumni

- Feedback from visiting committee

- Regular programme reviews

courses.description: This course introduces the concepts, as well as practices and skills that are widely used in evaluating environmental consequences resulting from anthropogenic activities. Students will be introduced to methods in assessment of environmental impact such as habitat and protected species surveys.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.course_syllabus:
- Hong Kong EIA system

- Stakeholder engagement and public consultation

- Basic principles and concepts of ecological, noise, water, air quality assessments

- Case studies

- Implications and challenges

courses.subject: BEST
courses.title: Zoological Diversity and Pest Management
courses.description: This course presents the diversity of the major lineages of animals. The concepts and recent advance in animal phylogeny will be introduced and the enormous diversity of animals will be introduced through an evolutionary journey. We will discuss the major structural, anatomical and physiological characteristics in respect to the origin and adaptive radiation of animals. Second half of the course focus into the intricate relationship between zoological diversity and effective pest management strategies. Students will study the principles of zoological diversity conservation and its significance in sustainable pest control practices. Through a combination of theoretical knowledge and practical applications, students will gain insights into the cost and benefit of integrated pest management approaches, aiming to minimize environmental impact while effectively managing pest populations. By the end of this course, students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills needed to address pest challenges while promoting biodiversity conservation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will

1. Understand the diversity and evolutionary relationships among animals

2. Understand the basic structure and function of different groups of invertebrates and vertebrates

3. Understand the adaptation and limitations of different groups of animals in respect to their ecological role.

4. Understand the economic, ecological, and sociological benefits for proper pest management

5. Understand the principle and pros/cons for different pest control tactics

6. Understand the main considerations (cost and benefits) for implementation of an effective pest control program
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Broad classification of Animal Kingdom and Principles of Taxonomy

Week 2: Molecular phylogenetic and new insights into animal evolution

Week 3-4: Invertebrates: Arthropoda, Mollusc, Annelida and Echinodermata

Week 5-6: Vertebrates: origin and adaptative radiation

Week 7: Biological Control: Theory and Application

Week 8: Introduction to common pests

Week 9-11: Control Tactics: Principle, effectiveness and considerations

Week 12: Integrated pest management: Policy and implementation

Week 13: Challenges and monitoring of pest management
courses.feedback_evaluation: Feedback from students will be collected through course evaluation. Continuous feedback, comments or questions are encouraged through communications via email, post-lecture discussion or CUHK e-forum (Blackboard Learn).
courses.required_readings: Lecture handouts will be available on Blackboard. Furthermore, journal articles that relate to the recent development in the field will also be recommended during the course.
courses.recommended_readings: Lecture handouts will be available on Blackboard. Furthermore, journal articles that relate to the recent development in the field will also be recommended during the course.

courses.description: This course will equip students with knowledge of micro-organisms and plants, as well as current technologies and measures for the protection of plant species as well as the applications of microbiology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

- acquire knowledge and techniques related botany, mycology, and microbiology

- recognise the nature and impacts of plants, fungi, and microbes

- understand and apply the technologies and measures for the protection of plant species, as well as the applications of microbiology
courses.course_syllabus:
- Non-vascular plants

- Vascular plants

- Fungi

- Microbes

- Technologies and Applications

courses.subject: BEST
courses.title: Literature Research in BEST

meetings.instructor:
Dr. LAW Man Suet Michelle, 
Professor CHAN Ting Fung Philos, 
Professor CHUI Pui Yi, 
Professor HUI Jerome Ho Lam, 
Professor LAM Hon Ming, 
Professor LUO Haiwei, 
Professor Michael David PITTMAN, 
Professor Shelby Eileen MC SHARRY MC ILROY, 
Professor TSANG Ling Ming, 
Professor TSUI Tsz Ki Martin, 
Professor ZHONG Silin

courses.description: Students, with the help of a supervisor, will identify a specific topic in the field of Biodiversity, Environmental Management, Sustainability and Technology (BEST) to perform literature research, and critically assess the scientific basis of the conclusions drawn. Students will discuss regularly with the supervisor and summarize the research findings in an oral presentation and a review paper.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

- demonstrate in-depth knowledge of the scientific method and research management principles.

- develop competencies in finding, reading, and critically evaluating relevant scientific literature.

- acquire skills in information searching, scientific writing and oral communication.

- master generic skills such as critical thinking and lifelong learning techniques.

- apply the basic statistical concepts and perform statistical analysis of biological data.

- recognize the importance of academic honesty.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Start a Scientific Project Using ‘Scientific Method’

- How to Write a Scientific Document

- Scientific Conduct and Ethical Issues

- Basic Statistics for Handling Experimental Data

- Discussion with students

courses.subject: BEST
courses.title: Research Project on BEST
courses.description: In this course, students will acquire hands-on experience of performing a research project on a current topic in biodiversity, conservation, or environmental management under the supervision of a teaching staff. Students will be required to analyse the data, and summarise them in the format suitable for an international peer-reviewed academic journal.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Biodiversity, Environmental Management, sustainability and Technology
Pre-requisite: BEST5300 and BEST5380
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction for research-type M.Sc. Project

- Rules and Safety in research labs

- Conduct a research project on a current topic in biodiversity, conservation, or environmental management under the supervision
courses.feedback_evaluation:
- Discussion with students
